frame.name: Candidness
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication. These words, analogously to behaver-evaluating words, can apply either to <fen>Speaker</fen>s or to the <fen>Message</fen>s they produce. They can occur with <ment>about</ment>-PPs expressing <fen>Topic</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Speaker">Evelyn</fex> was <t>candid</t> <fex name="Addressee">with me</fex> <fex name="Topic">about the party</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses. <ex><fex name="Spkr">Evelyn</fex> was <t>candid</t> about the party. </ex><ex>Evelyn is a <t>candid</t> <fex name="Spkr">person</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Addressee
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Addressee</fen> is the person to whom the <fen>Message</fen> is communicated. This FE often remains unexpressed. When expressed, it normally takes the form of a PP Complement headed by <ment>with</ment>. <ex>Evelyn was <t>candid</t> <fex name="Add">with me</fex> about the party.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Message
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This FE does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use. <ex>Evelyn made some <t>candid</t> <fex name="Msg">remarks</fex>. </ex><ex><fex name="Msg">Evelyn's remarks</fex> were <t>candid</t>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> FE in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by "about". <ex>Evelyn was <t>candid</t> <fex name="Top">about the party</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed. <ex>Evelyn made some <t>candid</t> remarks <fex name="Medium">in French</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Degree</fen> to which a communication is candid--some are more candid than others.
<ex>Evelyn's remarks were <fex name="Degree">very</fex> <t>candid</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates the manner of candidness. <ex>"He was a fool," John pointed out with <fex name="Mnr">ruthless</fex> <t>candour</t>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: blunt.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: uncompromisingly forthright in manner.

lexUnit.name: candid.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: truthful and straightforward; frank.

lexUnit.name: coy.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: reluctant to give details about something sensitive.

lexUnit.name: discreet.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: careful and prudent in one's speech or actions, especially so as to avoid giving offence or attracting attention.

lexUnit.name: explicit.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: clear and detailed, with no room for confusion or doubt.

lexUnit.name: forthcoming.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: willing to divulge information.

lexUnit.name: forthright.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: direct and outspoken.

lexUnit.name: frank.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: candid and honest.

lexUnit.name: honest.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: free of deceit; truthful and sincere.

lexUnit.name: open.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: frank and communicative.

lexUnit.name: outspoken.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: frank in stating one's opinions.

lexUnit.name: secretive.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: inclined to conceal feelings and intentions or not to disclose information.

lexUnit.name: sincere.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: proceeding from or characterized by genuine feelings; free from pretence or deceit.

lexUnit.name: straightforward.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: honest and open.

lexUnit.name: truthful.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: telling or expressing the truth; honest.

lexUnit.name: disingenuous.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: not candid or sincere, especially in pretending that one knows less about something than one really does

lexUnit.name: evasive.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: tending to avoid commitment or self-revelation, especially by responding only indirectly.

lexUnit.name: circumspect.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: cautious or prudent

lexUnit.name: honesty.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the quality of being honest

lexUnit.name: ingenuous.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: innocent, artless, and unsuspecting

lexUnit.name: bluntness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality of being blunt

lexUnit.name: candour.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the quality of being open and honest.

lexUnit.name: forthrightness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: being direct and outspoken

lexUnit.name: straight.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: not evasive; honest.

lexUnit.name: earnest.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: sincere and serious in intention

lexUnit.name: earnestness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: being serious and sincere in intention

lexUnit.name: dishonest.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: not honest, trustworthy, or sincere

lexUnit.name: devious.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: not straightfoward, characterized by insincerity or deceit

lexUnit.name: true.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: Honest, forthright
